author: By John Markoff
title: A Big Step Toward Fusion Energy Is Hailed by a Seattle Start-Up
description: Zap Energy said its experimental reactor core was ready for a milestone test. Skeptics routinely question whether the technology is currently possible.
content: Zap Energy, a fusion energy start-up working on a low-cost path to producing electricity commercially, said last week that it had taken an important step toward testing a system its researchers believe will eventually produce more electricity than it consumes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays and Grace Ashford
title: Ocasio-Cortez Endorses Insurgent in New York Lt. Governor’s Race
description: Ana María Archila, who would be the first Latina elected statewide, gained national attention after she confronted a senator over the Supreme Court confirmation of Brett Kavanaugh.
content: For much of her first term, Representative Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez raised her profile by fighting for nationwide initiatives favored by the far left, like Medicare for All and the Green New Deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cora Engelbrecht and Safak Timur
title: Saudi Leader Visits Turkey, Moving to Mend Rift Over Journalist’s Murder
description: The 2018 killing and dismemberment of the Saudi dissident and journalist Jamal Khashoggi by Saudi agents in Istanbul drove a deep wedge between the two countries.
content: The crown prince of Saudi Arabia visited Turkey on Wednesday for the first time since Saudi agents murdered the prominent dissident and journalist Jamal Khashoggi in Istanbul in 2018, driving a deep rift between the two regional powers.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Young U.S. children start getting vaccines, but hurdles remain.
description: Although opening up shots for children under 5 is a milestone, this long-awaited phase of the U.S. immunization effort is being greeted with mixed emotions.
content: Parents who experienced more than two years of anxiety may have felt some relief on Tuesday now that much of the United States has begun administering coronavirus vaccines to children younger than 5, allowing babies and toddlers to more safely explore the world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Noam Scheiber
title: Labor Agency Seeks Broad Order Against Starbucks in Federal Court
description: The National Labor Relations Board is aiming to stop what it says is extensive illegal activity by the coffee chain amid a national union campaign.
content: Federal labor regulators have asked a court to force Starbucks to stop what they say is extensive illegal activity in response to a nationwide campaign in which workers at more than 150 corporate-owned stores have voted to unionize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Dressing Simply, but Well. It’s Not So Simple.
description: Upselling the suit was on the agenda during this Milan Fashion Week, when Italian men’s wear returned in glory.
content: MILAN — Conjuring the pleasures of being “well, but simply, dressed” is how Brunello Cucinelli describes a design brief that has turned him, the son of an Umbrian farmer, into a self-made billionaire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Lydia DePillis
title: Biden Pushes Congress for Three-Month Gas Tax Holiday
description: Vulnerable Democrats have championed the move ahead of the midterm elections, but experts remain skeptical that suspending the federal tax would benefit consumers much.
content: WASHINGTON — With fuel prices near record highs, President Biden on Wednesday urged Congress to temporarily suspend the federal gas tax and give Americans “just a little bit of breathing room,” even as the proposal faced dim prospects on Capitol Hill.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Taub
title: When Outrage Isn’t Enough to Bring Change
description: An examination of crises in the Americas — including school shootings in the U.S. — yields a sobering theory about why even a national outpouring of pain cannot always overcome political divides.
content: To hear more audio stories from publications like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ashley Southall
title: ‘Torso Killer’ Charged in Strangulation of Long Island Woman in 1968
description: DNA evidence linked Richard Cottingham to the killing of Diane Cusick, prompting Nassau County prosecutors to review 13 years of unsolved murders of women.
content: When Diane Cusick’s last class for the evening ended on Feb. 15, 1968, the 23-year-old children’s dance instructor went to a Long Island mall to buy a pair of shoes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shane Goldmacher
title: Katie Britt Wins in Alabama as Trump Suffers More Losses in Georgia
description: In a handful of Southern states on Tuesday, Trump-backed candidates added to the former president’s mixed record in midterm primaries.
content: Katie Britt, a former chief of staff to the retiring Senator Richard C. Shelby of Alabama, won the Republican nomination to replace her onetime boss on Tuesday, comfortably defeating a right-wing rival in a race that puts the 40-year-old on track to become the youngest woman in the United States Senate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carlos Aguilar
title: Penélope Cruz, Antonio Banderas and Their ‘Official Competition’
description: The two Spanish actors discuss working together on a satire about the film industry, how they feel about awards and how they get into character.
content: That the international stars Penélope Cruz and Antonio Banderas had never spent more than two minutes together on the big screen is a surprising truth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: Biden’s top trade negotiator defended China tariffs as an important source of leverage.
description: The Biden administration has come under pressure to ease tariffs as a way to help deal with inflation.
content: Lawmakers on Wednesday pressed President Biden’s top trade negotiator over the administration’s trade strategy toward China, including what, if anything, Mr. Biden planned to do about tariffs on Chinese goods that were imposed by his predecessor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: Muna’s Fresh Start
description: The indie-pop band was dropped by its major label early in the pandemic, then scored a TikTok hit with “Silk Chiffon,” featuring a verse from its new label boss: Phoebe Bridgers.
content: The members of Muna kept calling themselves “impenetrable.” They were sorry about this, they insisted, as each lurched into the frame of a video call from a backyard in Los Angeles, ping-ponging inside jokes and rearranging themselves into different configurations.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: Gadgets Were Hot. Now They’re Not.
description: Not long ago, it seemed impossible to find a laptop. The pandemic has upended that, too.
content: A lot of companies have been caught off guard by changes in our spending choices this year. Americans eager to travel and party after two years of staying largely at home are gorging on plane tickets and fancier clothes — and ignoring the patio furniture and soft pants that we splurged on in 2020.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen and Laetitia Vancon
title: Linchpin of Ukrainian Defiance, a Southern City Endures Russian Barrage
description: Without its Black Sea coast, a landlocked Ukraine would struggle. Mykolaiv is determined that won’t happen.
content: MYKOLAIV, Ukraine — There is no door on Anna Svetlaya’s fridge. A Russian missile blew it off the other day. The detached door saved her, protecting her chest from shrapnel as she passed out in a pool of blood.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By McKenna Oxenden
title: Jaylon Ferguson, Baltimore Ravens Linebacker, Dies at 26
description: Mr. Ferguson was unresponsive when he was found in a house in North Baltimore, the authorities said. The Baltimore police said investigators “are not ruling out the possibility of an overdose.”
content: Jaylon Ferguson, an outside linebacker who was entering his fourth season with the Baltimore Ravens, died after the authorities found him unresponsive in a North Baltimore home late Tuesday, the police said. He was 26.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Tony Siragusa, a Defensive Lineman Known as Goose, Dies at 55
description: Siragusa won a Super Bowl with the Baltimore Ravens in the 2000 season and worked as a broadcaster after his playing career.
content: Tony Siragusa, the Super Bowl-winning defensive tackle and football television analyst for Fox Sports, died on Wednesday, owners of the Indianapolis Colts and the Baltimore Ravens said. He was 55 years old.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: The G.O.P. Tries to Build a Gay Ghetto
description: Conservatives are launching a broad attack on gay rights and gay culture.
content: This past weekend, the Republican Party in Texas voted on an outrageous platform that not only denies the results of the 2020 presidential election, but also rejects gay marriage and seeks to “protect” minors until they turn 17 against “predatory sexual behaviors,” such as drag queens reading stories aloud to children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Cohen
title: Clean energy investment lags as oil and gas prices soar.
description: The head of the International Energy Agency said high prices for fossil fuels would probably persist for years.
content: Oil and gas prices are likely to remain inflated for years given the uneven transition to cleaner energy sources, the head of the International Energy Agency said Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jim Rutenberg and Benjamin Mullin
title: Rupert Murdoch and Jerry Hall Are Said to Be Divorcing
description: The media mogul’s fourth divorce is unlikely to change the ownership structure of Mr. Murdoch’s empire, but it could reverberate through companies such as Fox News and The Wall Street Journal.
content: Rupert Murdoch, the media titan, and Jerry Hall, the model and actress, are getting divorced, according to two people with knowledge of the decision. The people would speak only anonymously to discuss a personal matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson
title: Britain’s inflation rate climbs to 9.1 percent, a fresh 40-year high.
description: The latest data comes during crippling train strikes as workers demand pay in line with the rising cost of living.
content: Prices in Britain climbed 9.1 percent in May from a year earlier, a slight acceleration in the inflation rate that was released during  a week of transit disruption as transport workers strike for, among other things, pay increases in line with the cost of living.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: A pivotal showdown approaches in eastern Ukraine as more villages fall to Russia.
description: Approaching a pivotal moment in their invasion of Ukraine, Russian forces have tightened their vise around two key eastern cities, raising the risk their slow, brutal advance will capture the cities and trap the Ukrainian troops defending them.
content: Approaching a pivotal moment in their invasion of Ukraine, Russian forces have tightened their vise around two key eastern cities, raising the risk their slow, brutal advance will capture the cities and trap the Ukrainian troops defending them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: What Should You Do When Your Partner Lies About His Earnings?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on a financial betrayal — and more.
content: My significant other and I have committed to being life partners. After living together for a year, we bought a house. We split the purchase cost and the cost of extensive renovations 50-50. We own the house in joint tenancy. We do not share any expenses other than household expenses and split those costs based on income. I have been very open about my finances and willingly give my partner access to all my accounts as he is retired from a career as a successful financial adviser.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Trevor Noah Calls Out Rudy Giuliani for Being ‘Thirsty’
description: “Yeah, Rudy made so many unanswered calls, the iPhone started labeling him as spam,” Noah said.
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Grose
title: Black Maternal Mortality Is Still a Crisis
description: Linda Villarosa’s new book, ‘Under the Skin,’ shows just how urgent the problem is.
content: As I was preparing to interview Linda Villarosa, the author of a new book, “Under the Skin: The Hidden Toll of Racism on American Lives and on the Health of Our Nation,” I saw a headline that reinforced how urgent her book’s message is: “CDC: Maternal mortality disparities have worsened.” The story, from Axios, showed in stark graphics how the maternal mortality gap between Black mothers and mothers of other races has only become larger since 2018. In 2020, the most recent year for which we have data, the maternal mortality rate per 100,000 births was 55.3 for Black women, 19.1 for white women and 18.2 for Hispanic women.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Newsmax Debate Lends N.Y. Governor’s Race a Far-Right Glow
description: The four Republican candidates for governor of New York faced off in their third and final debate before the June 28 primary.
content: The four Republican candidates for governor of New York made their closing pitch to voters on Tuesday night, voicing devotion to President Trump and his policies, disdain for gun control and abortion, and worries about crime and immigration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: Uvalde School District Puts Police Chief on Leave After Mass Shooting
description: The state’s top police official faulted Chief Pete Arredondo for delaying the confrontation with a gunman who killed 21 people in an elementary school last month.
content: HOUSTON — The chief of the school district police force in Uvalde, Texas, was placed on administrative leave after the state’s top police official faulted him for delaying the confrontation with a gunman at Robb Elementary School last month, the school district said on Wednesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: Could New York City Lose Its Last Remaining Jewish Congressman?
description: Three decades ago, Jewish lawmakers made up roughly half of New York City’s House delegation. Now there is one: Jerrold Nadler, who faces a tough primary battle.
content: The clock was nearing midnight on Shavuot, the Jewish Feast of Weeks, when Ruth W. Messinger offered a prophetic political warning to a crowd munching on holiday cheesecake at the Jewish community center on Manhattan’s Upper West Side.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘The Argument'
title: Is Crime That Bad, or Are the Vibes Just Off?
description: A debate on the reality of crime in America with ​​Alex Kingsbury and Rafael Mangual.
content: From New York to San Francisco, there’s a sense that crime is on the rise in American cities. And in some ways, that’s true: Violent crime has risen. Murders are up nearly 40 percent since 2019. But property crime has fallen for years. And how we define crime, and what’s causing its increase, is a complicated issue — as is what we should do about it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Bilefsky
title: Kaliningrad, Russia’s Westernmost Outpost, Is Again a Flash Point in East-West Relations
description: Wedged between Poland and Lithuania and bristling with missiles capable of flinging conventional or nuclear warheads into Europe, Kaliningrad has become emblematic of the Cold War era.
content: A former American national security adviser once called Kaliningrad, a Russian enclave sandwiched between the NATO members Poland and Lithuania, “a dagger in the heart of Europe.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: M.T.A. Vows to Make Subways 95% Accessible. It Will Take 33 Years.
description: The M.T.A. will spend billions to add elevators and ramps to stations over the next several decades, settling lawsuits accusing it of violating the rights of people with disabilities.
content: New York has lagged for years behind other major American cities in making its subway system accessible to people with disabilities: Just 126 of its 472 stations, or 27 percent, have elevators or ramps that make them fully accessible.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Powell says the Fed is ‘not trying to provoke’ a recession, but it is ‘certainly a possibility.’
description: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, testified before a Senate committee at a moment of rapid inflation and rising interest rates.
content: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, said that the central bank might be able to lower rapid inflation without tipping America into a painful downturn, though he cautioned that pulling it off would be “very challenging” to achieve and that a recession is “certainly a possibility.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Sima
title: Remember Pizza Rat? Meet Pollinator Rat.
description: In a city in Colombia, researchers say, common rodents help a plant produce fruit when they snack on its flower petals.
content: Birds do it. So do bees. Especially bees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Barbaro, Rachel Quester, Mooj Zadie, Nina Feldman, Jessica Cheung, Rob Szypko, Patricia Willens, Lisa Chow, Paige Cowett, Marion Lozano, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: How Biden’s Approval Rating Got So Low
description: Heading into the midterms, Democratic candidates are contending with the unpopularity of their party’s leader.
content: During his campaign for president and in his first year in office, Joe Biden tried to be all things to all people. But trying to govern on behalf of such a broad political coalition has left his administration with something of an identity crisis.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Mike Pence is expected to wade into the New York governor’s race by backing Lee Zeldin.
description: Mr. Pence’s endorsement comes in the final days of a contentious Republican primary for governor.
content: Former Vice President Mike Pence on Wednesday was expected to announce his endorsement of Representative Lee Zeldin for governor of New York, days before the Long Island congressman faces Rudolph W. Giuliani’s son and two other candidates in a Republican primary on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: The Avatars Wear Prada
description: And Balenciaga and Thom Browne. Meta opens a new fashion store for the metaverse. Should you shop?
content: So that’s it.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Big Returns for Investing in Fine Wine and Whiskey? It Was Fraud, U.S. Says.
description: The scheme, which the authorities say used “aggressive and deceptive tactics,” defrauded more than 150 people of about $13 million, according to court documents.
content: One company claims on its website that purchasing its whiskey can “help you acquire a piece of history.” Another says it specializes in the acquisition and sale of “the world’s most illustrious exciting and pleasurable Investment Grade” wines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Endangered Languages Are Worth Saving
description: We are honoring the Top 11 winners of our Student Editorial Contest by publishing their essays. This one is by Zoe Yu, age 17.
content: This essay, by Zoe Yu, age 17, from The Woodlands College Park High School in The Woodlands, Texas, is one of the Top 11 winners of The Learning Network’s Ninth Annual Student Editorial Contest, for which we received 16,664 entries.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: $3.2 Million Settlement in Police Killing of Daunte Wright
description: The settlement was reached months after a former Brooklyn Center, Minn., police officer was sentenced to two years in prison for the fatal shooting of Mr. Wright during a traffic stop.
content: The city of Brooklyn Center, Minn., has agreed to pay a $3.2 million settlement to the family of Daunte Wright, a 20-year-old Black man who was fatally shot by a police officer during a traffic stop in April 2021 near Minneapolis. The officer said she meant to fire her Taser instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julian E. Barnes
title: Pentagon Pressed to Review How It Judges an Ally’s Will to Fight
description: Lawmakers say the U.S. government failed to provide accurate assessments amid the conflicts in Ukraine and Afghanistan.
content: WASHINGTON — Congress is poised to force the Pentagon to study how it assesses allies’ will to fight, amid criticism from lawmakers that the U.S. government has regularly failed to make such assessments accurately.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Safiullah Padshah, Alissa J. Rubin and Mike Ives
title: Devastating Afghanistan Earthquake Leaves More Than 1,000 Dead
description: The quake — the deadliest in the country in two decades — was the latest in a string of tragedies to affect the country since the Taliban seized power from the U.S.-backed government last summer.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — For much of the past two decades, the southeastern part of Afghanistan near the Pakistani border was plagued by insurgent activity, as police and military posts were frequently overwhelmed by Taliban fighters, and received few benefits from the American military presence.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Drake Hits the Nightclub
description: How did the rapper arrive on the dance floor? And what subcultures and expectations might he experiment with next?
content: In the past, Drake has been focused on rewiring hip-hop with melody. But his seventh solo studio album, “Honestly, Nevermind” — which arrived as a surprise, with an elaborate nine-and-a-half-minute video for the track “Falling Back” — is an unanticipated pivot toward the dance floor. Drake has long included moments like this on his albums, but they rarely shaped the narrative. But now, for the first time, production that is hard-knocking and up-tempo is reshaping his sound.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives and John Yoon
title: ‘Not in This for the Money’: Why Some Families Sue North Korea
description: Families whose relatives have been abducted or imprisoned by North Korea are seeking to hold the country financially accountable despite the long odds of collecting money from the isolated nation.
content: SEOUL — A grieving couple in Ohio, a retired preschool teacher in South Korea and a woman who left Japan 62 years ago have one thing in common: They are among a small number of people who have sued North Korea.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Who won and who lost in Tuesday’s elections.
description: Katie Britt will most likely represent Alabama in the Senate, and two Republican House candidates in Georgia who had been backed by former President Donald J. Trump were defeated.
content: Voters in Alabama, Georgia, Virginia and Washington, D.C., weighed in on elections for the Senate, House and other offices on Tuesday. And officials in Texas announced the results of a recount in a closely watched Democratic primary for the House.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: WEDNESDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Vivian Hewitt, Who Amassed a Major Collection of Black Art, Dies at 102
description: Ms. Hewitt, a librarian, and her husband used their keen eyes and connections in New York to buy works by Romare Bearden, Jacob Lawrence and others.
content: Vivian Hewitt was easy to shop for. Not for her the old standards — flowers, perfume, perhaps a new television. No clothing or jewelry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Grace Lee
title: What’s the Plan for the Tampon Shortage?
description: As some consider switching to reusable menstrual products, factors like cost, accessibility and long-held personal preferences could be barriers.
content: Menstrual care products are personal, practically by definition. Various methods are passed down by family and trusted friends, carefully explained or hastily taught in bathroom stalls. Once people find a product that works for them, they tend to stick with it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Shooting on San Francisco Train Leaves 1 Dead and 1 Injured, Police Say
description: The authorities said that no arrests had been made and that the shooting appeared to be an isolated event. They were still looking for the attacker, who opened fire during an argument.
content: An attacker opened fire on a light rail train in San Francisco on Wednesday morning, killing one person during an argument and injuring a bystander before running out of the train, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilaria Parogni and Mihir Zaveri
title: Understanding Rent Regulation in N.Y.C.
description: Rent-stabilized apartments in the city are due to have their largest rent increase in almost a decade.
content: The rent-regulation system has been in place for decades to help insulate rents from market forces, and rent-stabilized homes remain a crucial component of New York City’s dwindling affordable housing stock. The panel that regulates the rents of roughly one million homes across New York City has approved some of the largest increases in years. Here’s what you should know about how this system works.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Javier C. Hernández
title: The Netrebko Question
description: The Russian soprano Anna Netrebko is opera’s biggest star. But her career is in disarray because of her ties to Putin, and arts companies around the world are divided on whether to welcome her back.
content: MONTE CARLO — Anna Netrebko, the superstar Russian soprano, stood on the steps of the ornate Casino de Monte-Carlo, taking photos with friends and watching Aston Martins and Ferraris zoom through the night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa and Blake Hounshell
title: Katie Britt leveraged her Alabama connections and political savvy to trounce Mo Brooks.
description: Ms. Britt, now the state’s Republican nominee for Senate, made her way to the top with an “Alabama First” message and skillful navigation of a rival’s fleeting Trump endorsement.
content: At a gathering of Alabama Republicans last year, Katie Britt and her husband strategically positioned themselves at the end of a receiving line to shake hands with former President Donald J. Trump.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Carter Hett
title: Risking Their Lives to Defy Hitler
description: Halik Kochanski’s “Resistance” traces the underground opposition to the Nazis across the continent of Europe.
content: For continental Europeans World War II was a vastly different experience than it was for the people of the British Commonwealth or the United States. In the English-speaking world the war was largely a long narrative of military operations happening somewhere else — sometimes going very badly, but always going, and ending in a comfortably self-affirming victory. They were spared the hardships, horrors, moral dilemmas and later recriminations of foreign occupation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: Lviv lays its sons to rest as the ranks of the war dead grow.
description: The funeral for a marine who loved the sport of parachuting was the first of four on Tuesday for local soldiers killed in heavy fighting against Russia in eastern Ukraine.
content: LVIV, Ukraine — Artemiy Dymyd’s closest friends unwrapped his parachute and spread it gently over his grave. The red, silky material swaddled his coffin as it was lowered down.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes
title: Many Russian Cyberattacks Failed in First Months of Ukraine War, Study Says
description: A report published by Microsoft also found that Moscow’s disinformation campaign to establish a narrative of the war favorable to Russia was doing better than expected.
content: WASHINGTON — A new examination of how Russia used its cybercapabilities in the first months of the war in Ukraine contains a number of surprises: Moscow conducted more cyberattacks than was realized at the time to bolster its invasion, but more than two-thirds of them failed, echoing its poor performance on the physical battlefield.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Are Large Corporate Profit Margins Causing Inflation?
description: New research suggests the answer is yes, in part.
content: Markups and profits of businesses in the United States last year were the highest since at least the 1950s, according to an analysis published on Tuesday by the Roosevelt Institute, a progressive think tank. This has raised questions about a possible relationship between corporate greed and inflation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell
title: Biden Just Proposed a Gas Tax Holiday. Will It Work?
description: The president’s idea isn’t a new one. Republicans like Glenn Youngkin and Ron DeSantis got there first.
content: When President Biden on Wednesday proposed a three-month suspension of federal taxes on gasoline and diesel, many Republicans rolled their eyes. And many Democrats wondered what had taken him so long.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane
title: Gun Bill’s Progress Reflects Political Shift, but G.O.P. Support Is Fragile
description: Only two of the 14 Republicans who broke ranks to support taking up gun legislation are facing voters this year, showing how difficult such deals could be in the future.
content: WASHINGTON — As Senator Joni Ernst, Republican of Iowa, weighed whether she should vote to take up a bipartisan gun reform measure, the phone lines in her offices were being flooded by constituents hoping to sway her.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas
title: Roger Goodell Defends Commanders Investigation, but Not Team’s Owner
description: The N.F.L.’s commissioner defended the league’s investigation into harassment claims against the Washington Commanders, but offered no support of the team’s owner, Daniel Snyder, who did not appear.
content: N.F.L. Commissioner Roger Goodell stood by the league’s investigation into allegations of workplace misconduct at the Washington Commanders organization at a congressional hearing on Wednesday, despite being challenged by House members about the N.F.L.’s decision not to compel a written report of the findings or to come down more harshly on the Commanders’ owner, Daniel Snyder.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah E. Bromwich and Jan Ransom
title: 3 N.Y.C. Detainees Die in Less Than a Week, Bringing Year’s Total to 9
description: The deaths came just a week after a judge gave New York City until the fall to come up with a plan for fixing Rikers to avoid a federal takeover.
content: In the week since a federal judge granted New York City at least another six months to reform its troubled jail system, three people who had recently been held at the troubled Rikers Island jail complex have died.

title: ‘It Was Really a Love Story.’ How an N.R.A. Ally Became a Gun Safety Advocate.

content: Allyson Felix isn’t done yet.

title: Under Pressure From LIV Golf, the PGA Tour Defends Its Perch
description: Jay Monahan, the tour’s commissioner, announced prize money increases for next year to try to appease players and called the rival circuit an “irrational threat” that was trying to “buy the sport.”
content: CROMWELL, Conn. — For the last month, as the upstart, Saudi-backed LIV Golf circuit has poached some of the most widely known players from the established PGA Tour, there has been speculation that eventually the rival organizations might have to learn to coexist.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Freddie Wilkinson
title: On a Divided Mount Everest, Climate Cooperation Is Being Tested
description: China and Nepal have both established unmanned weather stations high on the world’s tallest mountain.
content: A new landmark greeted mountaineers nearing the summit of Mount Everest this spring: a seven-foot-tall mast of scientific instruments bolted into the coarse shale of an outcropping known as Bishop Rock. It’s only about 130 vertical feet from the 29,032-foot summit, where one can look down the opposite side of the mountain, into China, and see another weather station about an equal distance from the top.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Rent Board Votes for 3.25% Increase on One-Year Leases
description: Two million New Yorkers who live in rent-stabilized apartments will be affected by increases approved at a raucous meeting of the Rent Guidelines Board.
content: Good morning. It’s Wednesday. We’ll look at rent increases that are on the way for two million New Yorkers. We’ll also catch up on the final debate between the Republicans running for governor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Brittney Griner’s Supporters Call on Biden to Strike a Deal to Free Her
description: The campaign by dozens of organizations representing people of color, women and L.G.B.T.Q. voters comes amid growing frustrations over the pace of the U.S. effort to bring her home.
content: Dozens of organizations representing people of color, women and L.G.B.T.Q. voters called on President Biden on Wednesday to strike a deal for the release of Brittney Griner, the W.N.B.A. star who has been detained in Russia since February.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $625,000 Homes in Oregon, Louisiana and Georgia
description: A Tudor Revival house in Portland, a Craftsman bungalow in Baton Rouge and a two-family home in Savannah.
content: This house is in the Woodstock neighborhood, on a quiet street a few blocks from a handful of coffee shops, a German deli and a grocery store specializing in local products. Reed College, a liberal arts school with about 1,500 undergraduate students and a number of early 20th-century Gothic Revival buildings, is less than five minutes away by car.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas B. Edsall
title: Why Conspiracy Theories Flourish in Trump’s America
description: “It is too soon to say whether this delegitimization is permanent,” one scholar says.
content: Whether he is out of power or in office, Donald Trump deploys conspiracy theory as a political mobilizing tool designed to capture anger at the liberal establishment, to legitimize racial resentment and to unite voters who feel oppressed by what they see as a dominant socially progressive culture.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ada Calhoun
title: The Poet Who Taught Me to Be in Love With the World
description: Frank O’Hara’s greatest legacy might be his secular faith — in other people, and in everything around us.
content: One day, while walking with my husband and 15-year-old son from the subway to the Central Park Zoo, we passed the William Tecumseh Sherman statue on the park’s southeast corner. As one might say a prayer upon passing a church, I recited the opening of Frank O’Hara’s 1954 poem “Music”:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Randall
title: A Source of Comfort in Our Search for Quantum Meaning
description: Effective theories in physics can help us measure and examine reality, despite the many things we do not yet know.
content: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What is reality? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Ng
title: Nonbinary Airline Passengers Ask: What’s Gender Got to Do With It?
description: Despite recent federal changes meant to better include gender-diverse travelers, most U.S. airlines still require passengers to select “male” or “female” when booking a ticket.
content: In late May, the chef Silver Cousler flew to Miami from Asheville, N.C., to have a “last hurrah” party ahead of getting married and a new restaurant opening. While booking the flight, Mx. Cousler, who identifies as nonbinary and uses the pronoun “they,” felt like they had “a split-personality disorder” when the Delta Air Lines website required them to choose either “male” or “female.”
source.name: The New York Times

description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)

author: By David Wallace-Wells
title: What’s Worse: Climate Denial or Climate Hypocrisy?
description: Today the rhetorical war has largely been won, but the outlook grows a lot more confusing when everyone agrees to agree.
content: In early 2020, Larry Fink — the chief executive of BlackRock, a financial firm whose $10 trillion in assets under management are roughly equivalent to the aggregate wealth of Latin America, and about twice that of Africa — did his best to stake his claim as the face of an environmentally responsible business future. “Climate change has become a defining factor in companies’ long-term prospects,” Fink wrote in his annual letter to C.E.O.s that year. He called global warming the most serious threat to the financial system in his 40 years of experience and promised a drastic response from his firm: making sustainability “integral to portfolio construction and risk management”; ditching investments that contribute to the problem; and pursuing not just sustainability but transparency, too, so we all could see what impacts the company was having.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emma G. Fitzsimmons, Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura and Téa Kvetenadze
title: Vaccinations for children under 5 start in New York City, including in Times Square.
description: In a city that was once the epicenter of the pandemic, many parents have been eager to vaccinate the last age group still awaiting shots.
content: Families in New York City began vaccinating children younger than 5 against Covid-19 on Wednesday after the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention endorsed the vaccines over the weekend and many parts of the United States started giving shots this week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eric Kim
title: This Chicken Salad Has It All
description: The all-you-can-eat buffet that inspired Eric Kim’s crunchy won-ton chicken salad is gone. But the flavors remain.
content: There’s a glow I used to feel when I left the Sweet Tomatoes in Alpharetta, Ga., that specific kind of smug radiance that comes from snagging a great deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amy Chang Chien
title: First Pineapples, Now Fish: To Pressure Taiwan, China Flexes Economic Muscle
description: Taiwan’s lucrative grouper industry is bracing for heavy losses after China’s recent ban on imports of the fish from the island.
content: FANGLIAO, Taiwan — Lin Chun-lai bought his grouper farm in southern Taiwan about a decade ago with an eye on mainland China’s growing appetite for live fish. In just a few years, the former electrician made enough money to comfortably support his family of four and even open a small inn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dionne Searcey
title: On the Congo River, Following a Logger’s Dangerous Journey
description: To understand the perilous, often illegal logging industry in the Congo Basin, we needed to get out on the water ourselves.
content: Our boat motored toward a sprawling port in Kinshasa, the capital of the Democratic Republic of Congo, and we stared in silence at the scene on the shore.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Meghan Stabile, Who Linked Jazz and Hip-Hop, Dies at 39
description: Shows that she produced on a shoestring sought to energize the jazz scene by connecting with younger audiences accustomed to D.J.s and turntables.
content: Meghan Stabile, who saw jazz and hip-hop as genres that could cross-pollinate and who, hoping to bring jazz to younger audiences, started a shoestring business producing concerts that explored the intersection of the two, died on June 12 in Valrico, Fla. She was 39.
source.name: The New York Times

description: An accident shines a light on the House speaker’s California life among the vineyards.
content: Speaker Nancy Pelosi had just urged Brown University graduates to stay resilient and summon their “better angels” on Memorial Day weekend when she was forced to turn her attention to a less uplifting situation: her husband’s arrest in California.

content: It’s almost July, which is typically the beginning of California’s fire season.

content: The Georgia Supreme Court on Wednesday overturned a father’s conviction on murder and other charges, nearly six years after he was found guilty of having deliberately left his toddler son to die in a hot car.

content: BASALT, Colo. — Claudia Cunningham had never voted for a Republican in her life. She swore she couldn’t or her father would roll over in his grave. But ahead of the Colorado primary on Tuesday, she did the once-unthinkable: registered as unaffiliated so that she could vote in the G.O.P. primary against her congresswoman, Lauren Boebert.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Jim Tankersley and Stacy Cowley
title: Inflation Complicates Biden’s Deliberations on Student Loan Forgiveness

content: WASHINGTON — The soaring cost of food, gasoline and other staples is further complicating a fraught debate among President Biden and his closest advisers over whether to follow through on his campaign pledge to cancel thousands of dollars of student loan debt for tens of millions of people.

content: WASHINGTON — The backlog of tax returns at the Internal Revenue Service has grown to more than 20 million in the last year despite efforts by the Biden administration to process filings and send out refunds more quickly, the national taxpayer advocate said in a report published on Wednesday.

source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rose Courteau, Kate Guadagnino and Miguel Morales
title: The 25 Most Significant New York City Novels From the Last 100 Years
description: Four writers and one bookseller gathered over Zoom to make a list devoted to fiction in which the city is more than mere setting.
content: What to say about New York? As both a place and an idea, it’s too big to be summed up or even fully known. But that hasn’t stopped countless writers from trying, often via fiction — which, like the city, lends itself to wandering. If anything, New York’s scale and complexity — the diversity of neighborhoods and industries and lives that coexist here — are what make it an inexhaustible and consistently compelling setting. There’s also the fact that it’s so closely associated with ambition, which, as any storyteller will confirm, tends to be a useful thing for a protagonist to have. And so, despite myriad differences in aims and style, the New York City novel has become its own literary category, one that T explored for this project, which compiles what we’ve deemed to be the 25 most influential New York novels published between 1921 and 2021.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Analysis: What Turkey Wants to Let Finland and Sweden Into NATO

title: Andrew Gillum, DeSantis’s 2018 Rival, Is Charged With Conspiracy and Fraud

description: Federal prosecutors sought information from two men who had worked on behalf of the Trump campaign and a third who signed up as a Trump elector in Georgia, a state won by President Biden.
content: The Justice Department stepped up its criminal investigation of a plan by President Donald J. Trump and his allies to create slates of so-called fake electors in a bid to keep Mr. Trump in power during the 2020 election, as federal agents delivered grand jury subpoenas on Wednesday to at least four people connected to the plan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bill Pennington
title: The Real Enforcers of Gender Equity in Sports: Angry Parents
description: Girls are supposed to have equal access in schools. In practice, districts aren’t forced to change unless someone speaks up.
content: A decade ago, Ginger Folger’s son, John, played high school football in Gainesville, Ga., their hometown, about 50 miles northeast of Atlanta.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Missing Letters
description: Kate Hawkins encourages us to move on.
content: WEDNESDAY PUZZLE — What luck! A Kate Hawkins puzzle to get us through Wednesday. This is Ms. Hawkins’s ninth appearance in the New York Times Crossword and her fourth on a Wednesday. I always enjoy the voice and personality that Ms. Hawkins brings to her puzzles, and today’s is no exception.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Matthew Cullen
title: Your Wednesday Briefing
description: Asia buys up Russian oil.
content: A surge in demand from Asia for discounted Russian oil is making up for the significantly lower number of barrels being sold to Europe, dulling the effects of the West’s sanctions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marcela Valdes
title: Inside the Push to Diversify the Book Business
description: For generations, America’s major publishers focused almost entirely on white readers. Now a new cadre of executives like Lisa Lucas is trying to open up the industry.
content: At the end of one of her first days on the job at Pantheon books in January 2021, Lisa Lucas picked up her iPad, settled into a couch and began swiping through the manuscript of an unpublished novel called “Sweet, Soft, Plenty Rhythm.” Written by Laura Warrell, the story follows a jazz musician and his entanglements with a dozen or so women. As Lucas devoured its pages, she slipped into a kind of trance. Hours ticked by. The sun set outside her windows, and still she could not stop reading.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colin Moynihan
title: Driver in Fatal Times Square Attack Found Not Responsible Because of Mental Illness
description: Richard Rojas, a Navy veteran, spiraled after he was discharged. Prosecutors said he was culpable, but failed to sway jurors in the 2017 attack that left one dead and injured nearly two dozen.
content: The maroon Honda seemed to appear in Times Square out of nowhere one day in the spring of 2017, swerving onto a curb on 42nd Street, then speeding north along the sidewalk on Seventh Avenue, striking more than 20 people and scattering dozens of others before ramming a bollard at 45th Street.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Vivian Giang, Stephen Gandel, Lauren Hirsch, Ephrat Livni, David F. Gallagher and Jenny Gross
title: Will Biden’s Gas Tax Holiday Make a Difference?
description: Many economists say suspending federal taxes on gas will not significantly cut prices for consumers.
content: This afternoon, President Biden will ask Congress to lift federal taxes on gas through the end of September, just before the midterm elections, The Times’s Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Lydia DePillis report. Oil prices have risen to their highest levels in 14 years, squeezing consumers, and the president is hoping to alleviate some of the economic pain that has been a drag on his popularity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Kim
title: The U.S. confirms the death of an American presumed to be the second killed on the battlefield in Ukraine.
description: The U.S. State Department on Wednesday confirmed the death of a man believed to be the second American killed fighting in Ukraine.
content: The U.S. State Department on Wednesday confirmed the death of a man believed to be the second American killed fighting in Ukraine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samuel Earle
title: It Feels Like Boris Johnson’s Britain Is Finally ‘Sinking Giggling Into the Sea’
description: The prime minister and his party have set the stage for the country’s woes.
content: LONDON — For Boris Johnson, Britain’s embattled and scandal-ridden prime minister, nowhere is safe.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Newly Published, From Cookie Stores to Jean Rhys
description: A selection of books published this week.
content: FRANCES IN THE COUNTRY, by Liz Garton Scanlon. Illustrated by Sean Qualls. (Neal Porter, $18.99, ages 4 to 8.) Frances is tired of city lights that say “stop.” So she visits the country, where she can “go go go.” Through spirited poetry and rough-and-tumble painted-collage art, this ebullient picture book shows us the best of both worlds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley, Lauren Herstik and Douglas Morino
title: Bill Cosby Loses Sex Assault Lawsuit and Must Pay Damages
description: A jury in California sided with Judy Huth, who accused Mr. Cosby of molesting her at the Playboy Mansion in 1975, when she was 16.
content: SANTA MONICA, Calif. — A jury on Tuesday found that Bill Cosby sexually assaulted Judy Huth in 1975, when as a 16-year-old girl she accepted his invitation to join him at the Playboy Mansion in Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: At 52, Mabou Mines Is Still Testing Boundaries
description: A three-day retrospective will shine a spotlight on the group’s most daring projects.
content: The word “crazy” comes up fairly regularly when talking to people about the Mabou Mines theater company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daisuke Wakabayashi
title: Chinese Businessman Tied to Alibaba Rape Case Is Sentenced to Prison
description: A court found Zhang Guo guilty of “forcible indecency.” The tech giant fired his accuser last year after she claimed that he had molested her and that her boss had raped her.
content: When a young female employee at Alibaba, one of China’s biggest technology firms, accused her manager and a company client of sexually assaulting her after an alcohol-fueled work dinner last summer, it seemed like a turning point for the country’s fledgling #MeToo movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Francesca Mari
title: The Man Who Made the Sari Haute
description: As his country’s most famous designer, Sabyasachi has persuaded Indians to see the luxury in their fashion heritage. Can he persuade Americans too?
content: In New York, Sabyasachi Mukherjee can almost be anonymous. He takes morning runs in Central Park; walks through Times Square, looking up at the billboards like a little kid; dines at family-run Chinese restaurants, the kinds of places where he’s unlikely to be photographed with a mouthful of food. Whenever he sees anyone from South Asia, he veers in the opposite direction, hoping to avoid an awkward encounter. But run-ins are inevitable, as when a fan stopped him recently coming out of the Plaza Hotel — a doctor from India, eager to exchange a word with India’s most famous fashion designer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamín Labatut
title: The Picaresque Life of the Man Who Modernized Neuroscience
description: Benjamin Ehrlich’s “The Brain in Search of Itself” is a lovingly crafted biography of the Spanish scientist (and artist, and hypnotist) who showed us what our brains are made of.
content: “The devil child,” his family called him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas
title: Panel Finds Daniel Snyder Interfered With Sexual Harassment Investigation
description: In a memo, a Congressional panel said it found evidence that the Washington Commanders owner conducted a “shadow investigation” of accusers.
content: As the N.F.L. was investigating his team for widespread workplace misconduct, the Washington Commanders owner Daniel Snyder directed a “shadow investigation” to interfere with and undermine its findings, a Congressional committee found.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Title IX Gave Women Greater Access to Education. Here’s What It Says and Does.
description: The law has grown participation for women and girls in sports and has had other significant ramifications, too.
content: On June 23, 1972, President Richard M. Nixon signed an omnibus education bill that would change the paths of millions of women and girls in the United States. At first glance, the sweep conveyed by the words themselves can be hard to recognize.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Imprint Ducklings
description: Hang around the ducklings right after they hatch. The birds open their eyes and immediately start looking for a caregiver.
content: “Ducklings will imprint on anything that moves that’s bigger than a matchbox,” says Antone Martinho-Truswell, who co-founded the Duckling Laboratory at the University of Oxford while getting his doctorate in zoology. Ducks are what scientists call precocial birds — capable of feeding, swimming and walking soon after hatching. Still, ducklings are vulnerable, which is why the little puffballs evolved to seek and memorize the image of their mothers. Should a duckling hatch and not see her, it will eagerly imprint on something else, like you.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Bailey
title: ‘Disappearance at Clifton Hill,’ ‘Damsel’ and More Streaming Gems
description: Inventive riffs on murder mysteries, westerns and gangster movies are among the highlights of this month’s under-the-radar streaming recommendations.
content: The director Albert Shin lays on the dread from the opening frames of this atmospheric Canadian thriller; something’s wrong here, even if we don’t yet know what. Abby (Tuppence Middleton) doesn’t know either, but she has spent most of her life haunted by the childhood incident that begins the film: a half-understood encounter at a lake during which she might have witnessed a kidnapping. Now, as an adult whose life is falling apart, she does what so many of us do: She ignores her own problems and becomes fixated on the increasingly peculiar details of a barely remembered incident. Shin has a way of unsettlingly creeping his camera and peering inquisitively into darkness (literal and figurative); the result is a solid, moody mystery about buried secrets and oddball history. Bonus: an appropriately odd appearance by the Canadian treasure David Cronenberg as a grizzled podcaster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Valerie Hopkins and Marc Santora
title: The arrival of Western weapons begins to reshape the battle off Ukraine’s coast.
description: The Ukrainian military said it was attacking Russian infrastructure on Snake Island.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — As Ukrainian forces launch a renewed assault on Snake Island in the Black Sea, recent strikes suggest that they are using powerful Western anti-ship weapons in an effort to undermine Russian naval domination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cy. Jillian Weise
title: How a Cyborg Challenges Reality
description: In a letter to a fellow poet, the author details a shared truth among disabled people.
content: This essay is part of a series called The Big Ideas, in which writers respond to a single question: What is reality? You can read more by visiting The Big Ideas series page.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: The Rookie Some Didn’t Want Now Has a Fan Base Feeling Optimistic
description: When Detroit drafted Moritz Seider, a contingent of fans had “pure shock and disappointment.” But after a strong rookie season, those fans hope he can help end a six-year playoff drought.
content: DETROIT — The Red Wings have completed their sixth consecutive losing season, but still there’s a buzz in the Motor City that one of the N.H.L.’s most storied franchises may finally be on the road back to prominence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Gardner
title: N.B.A. Draft Preview: A Deep Field Could Yield Surprise Stars
description: Fans may have heard of Chet Holmgren and Shaedon Sharpe, but others are ready for their shot: “I knew if I got good enough, the N.B.A. would find me,” one said.
content: When the Orlando Magic hand their draft card to N.B.A. Commissioner Adam Silver, on Thursday night at Barclays Center, they’ll settle a debate that has raged in draft circles for the better part of a year: Who should be the No. 1 pick?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Erik Vance
title: Kayaking: An Outdoor Adventure and a Full-Body Workout
description: Watercraft sales exploded during the pandemic, and many more garages now have kayaks in them. But do you know how to get the best workout in one?
content: Last year, my wife and I took a kayaking day trip to the tip of Point Reyes, a peninsula just north of San Francisco formed by the San Andreas Fault shoving a slice of California out to sea.
source.name: The New York Times
